message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of productive cough, multiple episodes of pneumonia, and bulky greasy stools suggest cystic fibrosis. The initial test to indicate its presence is a sweat chloride test. X-ray of the chest, serum immunoglobulin level, and DNA phenotyping are not specific enough to diagnose cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the multiple episodes of greasy stools and respiratory issues, suggest cystic fibrosis, which can be confirmed with a sweat chloride test. X-ray of the chest may show anatomical abnormalities but it will not confirm the underlying etiology. Serum immunoglobulin level and DNA phenotyping are not relevant in the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest cystic fibrosis, which is best diagnosed through a sweat chloride test. X-ray of the chest may show abnormalities, but it is not specific for cystic fibrosis. Serum immunoglobulin level is not diagnostic for cystic fibrosis. DNA phenotyping is not a commonly used diagnostic test for cystic fibrosis.

A sweat chloride test is the best initial test for diagnosis. X-ray of the chest may show abnormalities but is not specific to cystic fibrosis. Serum immunoglobulin level and DNA phenotyping are not relevant to the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including recurrent pneumonia and bulky greasy stools, suggest cystic fibrosis. The sweat chloride test is the best initial test to determine the underlying etiology of this patient's illness as it is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis. X-ray of the chest may show abnormalities but cannot confirm the diagnosis. Serum immunoglobulin level is not relevant to this condition, and DNA phenotyping is not currently used for diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

A chest x-ray may show some abnormalities but it is not the most specific test for cystic fibrosis. Serum immunoglobulin levels may be elevated in other illnesses but not specifically in cystic fibrosis. DNA phenotyping is not a standard diagnostic test for cystic fibrosis.

The symptoms, including the cough with productive phlegm, recurrent pneumonia despite antibiotic therapy, and greasy stools, suggest cystic fibrosis. The best initial test to confirm the diagnosis is a sweat chloride test. X-ray of the chest can show anatomical abnormalities but not necessarily confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Serum immunoglobulin levels and DNA phenotyping are not appropriate tests for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest cystic fibrosis, which is characterized by recurrent respiratory infections, malabsorption, poor growth, and a positive family history. Sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis. X-ray of the chest may be helpful in evaluating respiratory symptoms, but it is not specific for cystic fibrosis. Serum immunoglobulin levels are not typically abnormal in cystic fibrosis, and DNA phenotyping is not used for diagnosing cystic fibrosis.
